GENERAL PROVISIONS



§ 31.001  APPLICABILITY.



   The provisions of this subchapter shall apply alike to all officers and
employees of the village, regardless of the time of the creation of the
office or position or the time of the appointment of the officer or employee.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.002  ELECTION AND APPOINTMENT OF OFFICERS.



   (A)   Elections.  Elections for municipal offices shall be held as
provided by statute, and at the time prescribed by statute.



   (B)   Appointments.  All officers, other than elective officers and
police and fire officers under the jurisdiction of the Fires and Police
Commissioners, shall be appointed by the Village President by and with the
advice and consent of the Board of Trustees as provided by statute; provided
that all employees shall, in the absence of any ordinance or provisions to
the contrary, be appointed or selected by the Village President.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.003  TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES.



   (A)   Every appointive officer of the village shall hold office
until the last occurring May 1 following his appointment or until his
successor is appointed and qualified, unless it is otherwise provided by
ordinance.  In case of a vacancy in any such office, it shall be filled in
the same manner in which original appointments are made.



   (B)   Every officer and employee of the village, upon the expiration
of his term for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all
books and records which may be the property of the village, and if no
successor has been appointed within one week  after  the  termination 
of  such  term,  such property shall be delivered to the Village Clerk or
the Village Treasurer.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.004  OATH OF OFFICE.



   Every officer of the village shall, before entering upon his duties,
take the oath prescribed by statute.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



Statutory reference:



   Oath of office, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-10-25



§ 31.005  BONDS OF OFFICERS.



   (A)   (1)   Upon entering upon the duties of his office, each
village officer shall file with the Village Clerk a surety bond on such forms
and in such amounts as shall be approved by the President and Board of
Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of his or
her office; provided, however, that the bond of the Village Clerk shall be
filed with the Village Treasurer. Village employees who are not officers of
the village shall file with the Village Clerk bonds in such amounts as the
President and Board of Trustees may, from time to time, determine.



      (2)   The bond amounts shall be:



 


Officer

 

Amount





Village President
 

$3,000



Village Clerk
 

3,000



Village Treasurer
 

(3 times the latest federal census)



Village Administrator
 

25,000



Deputy Village Administrator
 

25,000



Police Chief
 

2,500



Director of Public Works
 

2,500



Director of Parks and Recreation
 

2,500



Budget Officer
 

1,000



Director of Administrative Services
 

2,500



Director of Community Development
 

2,500



Village Engineer
 

1,000





 



   (B)   (1)   Whenever a surety bond to indemnify the village is
required as a prerequisite to exercising the duties of any office or
position, or to the issuance of a license or permit or for the exercise of
any special privilege, the surety on such bond shall be a corporation
licensed and authorized to do business in this state as a surety company in
the absence of specific provision, by ordinance, to the contrary.



      (2)   Whenever in its opinion additional sureties or an
additional surety may be needed on any bond to indemnify the village against
loss or liability because of the insolvency of the existing surety or
sureties or for any other reason, the village may order a new surety or
sureties to be secured for such bond.  If such new order is transmitted to
the principal on the bond, or his assignee, the Board shall declare the bond
to be forfeited and such principal or assignee shall be deemed to have
surrendered the privilege or position as condition of which the bond was
required.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98; Am. Ord. 1998-43, passed 9-21-98; Am. Ord.
2001-44, passed 9-10-01; Am. Ord. 2007-21, passed 5-7-07; Am. Ord. 2015-20,
passed 4-20-15; Am. Ord. 2017-03, passed 2-6-17; Am. Ord. 2017-09, passed
2-21-17; Am. Ord. 2017-65, passed 10-16-17)



§ 31.006  SALARIES.



   (A)   The following salary scale for certain elected public
officials of the village is hereby established effective May 1, 2005:



      (1)   President:  $300 per meeting.



      (2)   Trustees:  $150 per meeting.



      (3)   Village Clerk:  $225 per meeting.



   For purposes of this section, a "meeting" shall include attendance at
any meeting of any Commission or Board established by ordinance that is
subject to the provisions of the Open Meetings Act.



   (B)   All other officers and employees of the village shall receive
such salary as may from time to time be provided by ordinance or resolution.



   (C)   Elected Officials may receive compensation for more than one
meeting per week but shall not receive compensation for more than one meeting
per calendar day.  Under circumstances approved by a majority of the
Corporate Authorities, an elected official may receive compensation for a
meeting he or she did not attend due to attendance at another event or
function related to his or her office.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98; Am. Ord. 2002-92, passed 10-7-02; Am. Ord.
2002-94, passed 10-21-02)



§ 31.007  RECORDS.



   All records kept by any officer of the village shall be open to
inspection by the Village President or any member of the Board of Trustees at
all reasonable times, whether or not such records are required to be kept by
statute or ordinance.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.008  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   Assignment of duties.  The Village President shall have the
power to assign to any appointive officer any duty which is not assigned by
ordinance to some other specific officer; and shall determine disputes or
questions relating to the respective powers or duties of officers.



   (B)   Moneys received.  Every officer of the village shall, at
least once each month, turn over all money received by him in his official
capacity to the Treasurer with a statement showing the source from which the
same was received.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.009  ADOPTION OF STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT.



   (A)   The regulations of Sections 5-15 (ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§
5-15) and Article 10 (ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 10-10 through 10-40) of the
State Officials and Employees Ethics Act, ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §§ 1-1 et
seq., (hereinafter referred to as the “Act” in this section) are hereby
adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of
this governmental entity to the extent required by ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §
70-5.



   (B)   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be
solicited or accepted under the Act, by any officer or any employee is hereby
prohibited.



   (C)   The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or
made to an officer or employee is hereby prohibited.



   (D)   The participation in political activities prohibited under the
Act, by any officer or employee is hereby prohibited.



   (E)   For purposes of this section, the terms “officer” and
“employee” shall be defined as set forth in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, §
70-5(c).



   (F)   The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same
as those penalties set forth in ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 50-5 for similar
violations of the Act.



   (G)   This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any
existing enactment which regulates the conduct of officers and employees. To
the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive
than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall prevail in
accordance with the provisions of ILCS Ch. 5, Act 430, § 70-5(a).



   (H)   Any amendment to the Act that becomes effective after the
effective date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by
reference and shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering
and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities.



However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption shall
not be incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by
this governmental entity.



   (I)   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares the Act
unconstitutional in its entirety, then this Section shall be repealed as of
the date that the Illinois Supreme Court's decision becomes final and not
subject to any further appeals or rehearings. This Section shall be deemed
repealed without further action if the Act is found unconstitutional by the
Illinois Supreme Court.



   (J)   If the Illinois Supreme Court declares part of the Act
unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the
Act, or does not address the remainder of the Act, then the remainder of the
Act as adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect;
however, that part of this section relating to the part of the Act found
unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by this
governmental entity.



   (K)   A violation of any provision of this section shall be punished
through the bringing of a quasi-criminal judicial complaint by an attorney
chosen in the manner provided by law for this governmental entity. That
prosecutor shall utilize prosecutorial discretion in enforcing this section
and may seek such penalties for a violation of this section as are allowed to
be sought under local or state law.



(Ord. 2004-33, passed 5-17-04; Am. Ord. 2011-47, passed 10-3-11)



VILLAGE PRESIDENT



§ 31.020  ELECTION; TERM OF OFFICE; TITLE.



   (A)   Election; term of office.  The Village President shall be
elected for a term of four years and shall be President of the Board of
Trustees, as is provided by statute.



   (B)   Title.



      (1)   The term VILLAGE PRESIDENT, as used in any ordinance,
resolution, motion or other action of the corporate authorities, shall be
construed as meaning the Mayor; and the term MAYOR wherever so used shall be
construed to mean the Village President.



      (2)   The title MAYOR, as used in the minutes of the meetings
of the corporate authorities or any other official document, shall be
construed as meaning “Village President.”



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



Statutory reference:



   Election and term of Village President, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §
3.1-15-10



   Definition of Mayor, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 1-1-2.1



§ 31.021  BOND, OATH AND SALARY.



   Before entering upon the duties of his office, the President shall give
a bond, with sureties to be approved by the Board of Trustees conditioned
upon the faithful performance of his duties, in the penal sum of $3,000.00. 
He shall take the oath of office as prescribed by statute.  For the salary
of the Village President, see § 31.006 of this code.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



Statutory reference:



   Oath of office, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-10-25



§ 31.022  GENERAL DUTIES.



   The Village President shall be the chief executive officer of the
village, and he shall perform all such duties as may be required by statute
or ordinance.  The Village President shall have the power and authority to
inspect all books and records kept by any village officer or employee at any
reasonable time.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.023  PRESIDENT PRO TEM.



   During the temporary absence or disability of the Village President,
the Board of Trustees shall elect one of its members to act as President Pro
Tem, who during the absence or disability of the President shall perform the
duties pertaining to the office. The President Pro Tem, during the absence or
disability of the Village President, shall perform the duties and possess all
the rights and powers of the Village President  but  shall  not be
entitled to  vote  both  as President Pro Tem and as Trustee.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98; Am. Ord. 1999-25, passed 5-17-99)



§ 31.024  TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN.



   In the absence of the Village President or President Pro Tem, the Board
of Trustees may elect one of their members to act as a Temporary Chairman.
The Temporary Chairman shall have only the powers of a presiding officer and
a right to vote only in the capacity as Village Trustee on any ordinance,
resolution, or motion.



(Ord. 1999-25, passed 5-17-99)



§ 31.025  CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT.



   In the event of a DISASTER or ATTACK as defined in the Emergency
Interim Succession Act, ILCS Ch. 5, Act 275, §§ 1 et seq. (the Act) and the
Village President cannot be located or is unable to exercise the powers of
the office or discharge the duties of the office, then the Village
Administrator is hereby designated as the emergency interim successor under
the Act with the authority to exercise the powers of the office of Village
President and the authority to discharge the duties of an office until a
successor is appointed or elected and qualified as may be provided by the
constitution, statutes, charters and ordinances, or until the lawful
incumbent is able to resume the exercise of the powers and discharge the
duties of the office. In the event that the Village Administrator cannot be
located or is unable to exercise the powers of the office, then for purposes
of continuity of government under the Act, the Chief of Police is named as
the next emergency interim successor to the office of Village President. In
the further event that that the Chief of Police cannot be located or is
unable to exercise the powers of the office, then for purposes of continuity
of government under the Act, the EMA Director is named as the next emergency
interim successor to the office of Village President.



(Ord. 2012-54, passed 12-3-12)



VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR



§ 31.030  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Village Administrator.



('81 Code, § 2-5.01) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.031  APPOINTMENT.



   (A)   The Village Administrator shall be appointed by the Village
President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, to
serve a term of one year, unless otherwise extended by contract but in no
event longer than the term of the current Village President. Removal from
office shall be in like manner in accordance with applicable state law and
contractual provisions. Said Administrator may hold another non-conflicting
municipal office, either elected or appointed. The confirmation of such
appointment shall be considered by the Board of Trustees solely on the basis
of executive and administrative qualification with special reference to
actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practices with respect to the
duties of the office hereinafter set forth, and such requirements and
qualifications are hereby declared to be of such a nature as to require
technical training or knowledge.



   (B)   The Deputy Village Administrator shall serve as the acting
Village Administrator when the Village Administrator is absent from his or
her office for more than two consecutive days. During an extended (more than
30 days) absence or disability of both the Village Administrator and the
Deputy Village Administrator, the Village President, with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees, may designate some properly qualified
person to act as Village Administrator pro tempore to perform the duties of
the office.



(‘81 Code, § 2-5.02) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98; Am. Ord. 2015-20,
passed 4-20-15)



§ 31.032  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond.  Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village
Administrator shalt furnish a surety bond in the amount to be approved by the
President and Board of Trustees, said bond to be conditioned on the faithful
performance of the Administrator's duties. The premium for the bond shall be
paid by the Village. The bond shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village
Administrator shall take and subscribe the oath required by the Illinois
Constitution. The subscribed oath shall be filed in the office of the Village
Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation. The Village Administrator shall receive
compensation in such amount and manner as the President and Board of Trustees
shall fix from time to time by contract or ordinance.



('81 Code, § 2-5.03) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.033  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The Village Administrator shall have the following powers and duties:



   (A)   Direct, supervise, and coordinate the administration of all
departments, offices, and agencies of the Village, except as otherwise
provided by law;



   (B)   Employ and, when necessary for the good of the Village,
suspend or remove all Village employees other than appointive administrative
officers. All employments and removals shall be subject to the Village of
South Elgin Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual and any applicable
contract. The Administrator may authorize any administrative officer, subject
to the Administrator's direction and supervision, to exercise these powers
with respect to subordinates in that officer's department, office, or agency;



   (C)   Attend all Village Board and other meetings as prescribed by
the Village President or Board of Trustees. It is understood that attendance
at these meetings is a fundamental component of the Administrator's duties,
and no additional compensation will be provided for attending said meetings;



   (D)   Provide for the enforcement of all laws and ordinances within
the Village;



   (E)   Serve as Budget Officer and prepare and submit to the Village,
by the date set by the Board, a recommended annual budget for Village
operations and a recommended capital program. When the annual budget or
capital program has been approved by the Village Board, the Administrator
shall be responsible for the administration of said budget or capital
program. The Administrator shall also prepare, or cause to be prepared, the
tax levy ordinance and upon enactment, file a certified copy with the County
Clerk;



   (F)   Submit to the Village Board and make available to the public a
complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the Village
at the end of each fiscal year; Make such other reports as the Village Board
may require concerning the operations of Village departments, offices, and
agencies;



   (G)   Keep the Village Board fully advised as to the present
financial condition and future needs of the Village;



   (H)   Advise the Village Board an pending decisions of public policy
and recommend to the Board the adoption of such measures as the Administrator
may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety, or welfare of the
community or for the improvement of administrative services;



   (I)   Be responsible for procurement of commodities and services for
all village departments, offices, and agencies, and promulgate purchasing
rules which shall be followed by employees in the procurement of goods and
services, provided that all purchase and other expenditures over $25,000
first shall be authorized by the Board unless otherwise provided by the
village.  The Administrator is authorized to engage consultant services for
any matter that will create an obligation for such services not exceeding
$25,000 without prior Village Board approval;



   (J)   Propose to the Village Board such personnel rules and
regulations as the Administrator deems necessary to manage the personnel
policies of the Village;



   (K)   Make recommendations to the Village President and Board of
Trustees concerning the classifications and compensation of each employee in
the Village service;



   (L)   Investigate all complaints in relation to the matters of
Village government and services;



   (M)   Provide staff support services for the Village President and
the Board of Trustees; and



   (N)   Perform such other duties as may be specified by law or
Village ordinance or as may from time to time be requested by the Village
President or Board of Trustees.



(‘81 Code, § 2-5.04) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98; Am. Ord. 2001-66,
passed 12-17-01; Am. Ord. 2005-34, passed 6-6-05; Am. Ord. 2017-65, passed
10-16-17)



DEPUTY VILLAGE ADMINISTRATOR



§ 31.040  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Deputy Village Administrator.



(Ord. 2015-20, passed 4-20-15)



§ 31.041  APPOINTMENT.



   (A)   The Deputy Village Administrator shall be appointed by the
Village President with the advice of the Village Administrator and the
consent of the Village Board of Trustees, to serve a term of one year, unless
otherwise extended by contract but in no event longer than the term of the
current Village President. Removal from office shall be in like manner in
accordance with applicable state law and contractual provisions. Said Deputy
Village Administrator may hold another non-conflicting municipal office,
either elected or appointed, including a department head position on an
interim basis. The confirmation of such appointment shall be considered by
the Board of Trustees solely on the basis of executive and administrative
qualification with special reference to actual experience in or knowledge of
accepted practices with respect to the duties of the office hereinafter set
forth, and such requirements and qualifications are hereby declared to be of
such a nature as to require technical training or knowledge.



   (B)   The Deputy Village Administrator shall serve as the acting
Village Administrator when the Village Administrator is absent from his or
her office for more than one consecutive day.



(Ord. 2015-20, passed 4-20-15)



§ 31.042  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Deputy
Village Administrator shall furnish a surety bond in the amount of $10,000,
said bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of the Deputy
Administrator’s duties. The premium for the bond shall be paid by the
village. The bond shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Deputy
Village Administrator shall take and subscribe the oath required by the
Illinois Constitution. The subscribed oath shall be filed in the office of
the Village Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation. The Deputy Village Administrator shall receive
compensation in such amount and manner as the President and Board of Trustees
shall fix from time to time by contract, ordinance, or motion.



(Ord. 2015-20, passed 4-20-15)



§ 31.043  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The Deputy Village Administrator shall have the following powers and
duties:



   (A)   Provide staff support services for the Village Administrator,
the Village President, and the Board of Trustees.



   (B)   Perform such other duties as may be specified by the Village
Administrator.



(Ord. 2015-20, passed 4-20-15; Am. Ord. 2016-57, passed 11-7-16)



VILLAGE CLERK



§ 31.050  ELECTION; TERM; VACANCY.



   The Village Clerk shall be elected and serve for a four year term and
until his or her successor is elected and qualified, as provided by statute.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



Statutory reference:



   Election and term of Village Clerk, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-25-90



§ 31.051  BOND; OATH.



   Before entering upon her duties of office, the Village Clerk shall
execute a bond in such amount and with such sureties as may be required by
the Board of Trustees, conditioned upon the faithful performance of his or
her duties.  The Village Clerk shall take the oath of office as prescribed
by statute..



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



Statutory reference:



   Oath of office, see ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 3.1-10-25



§ 31.052  GENERAL POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Village Clerk shall seal and attest all contracts of the
village and all licenses, permits and such other documents as shall require
this formality.



   (B)   Documents and records:



      (1)   The Village Clerk shall be the custodian of all
documents belonging to the village, which are not assigned to the custody of
some other officer.



      (2)   In addition to the record of ordinances and other
records which the Clerk is required by statute to keep, she shall keep a
register of all licenses and permits issued, and the payments thereon; a
record showing all of the officers of the village; and such other records as
may be required by the Board of Trustees.



      (3)   The Village Clerk shall keep and maintain a proper index
to all documents and records kept by her, so that ready access thereto and
use thereof may be had.



   (C)   The Village Clerk shall be the custodian of the village seal
and shall affix its impression on documents whenever this is required.



   (D)   The Village Clerk shall attend all meetings of the corporate
authorities and keep a full record of their proceedings in the village
minutes.  The record of those proceedings shall be made available for public
inspection  within  ten days after being  approved  or  accepted by the
corporate authorities as the official minutes of their proceedings.



   (E)   Village finances:



      (1)   The Village Clerk shall turn over all money received by
her on behalf of the village to the Village Treasurer promptly upon receipt
of the same; and with such money she shall give a statement as to the source
thereof.



      (2)   The Village Clerk shall keep accounts showing all money
received by her and the source and disposition thereof; and such other
accounts as may be required by statute or ordinance.



   (F)   In addition to the duties herein provided, the Village Clerk
shall perform such other duties and functions as may be required by statute
or ordinance.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.053  OFFICE HOURS.



   The Village Clerk's Office shall be located in the South Elgin Village
Hall and be open between 8:30 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday,
except on legal holidays and except as hereafter provided.  During said
office hours, the Village Clerk's office shall be readily available to assist
members of the general public with respect to village business.  The Village
Clerk's Office shall be closed on Saturdays and Sundays.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.054  SALARY.



   The Village Clerk shall receive an annual salary as set out in §
31.006 of this code.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



§ 31.055  DEPUTY CLERK.



   (A)   The Village Clerk is authorized to appoint a Deputy Clerk who
shall have the power and duty to execute all documents required by any law or
ordinance to be executed by the Clerk, and affix the seal of the village
thereto whenever required.



   (B)   When signing any documents, the Deputy Clerk shall sign the
name of the Village Clerk followed by the word “by” and the Deputy
Clerk's own name and the words “Deputy Clerk.”



   (C)   The powers and duties herein described shall be exercised by
such Deputy Clerk only in the absence of the Village Clerk from her office in
the Village Hall, and only when either written document has been given by the
Village Clerk to exercise such power, or the Village Board has determined by
resolution that the Village Clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated
to perform such function.  Such Deputy Clerk shall have the authority and
power herein described, and such further power and authority as may be
provided by statute.



(Ord. 1998-21, passed 4-20-98)



TREASURER



§ 31.060  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Treasurer.



('81 Code, § 2-6.01) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.061  APPOINTMENT.



   The Treasurer shall be appointed by the Village President by and with
the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, to serve a term of one year,
unless otherwise extended by contract, but in no event longer than the term
of the current Village President. Removal from office shall be in like manner
in accordance with applicable state law and contractual provisions. The
Treasurer may hold another non-conflicting municipal office, either elected
or appointed.



('81 Code, § 2-6.02) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.062  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Treasurer
shall furnish a surety bond in the amount to be approved by the President and
Board of Trustees, the bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of
the Treasurer's duties. The bond shall be an amount of money that is not less
than three times the latest Federal Census Population or any subsequent
census figure used for Motor Fuel Tax purposes. The premium for the bond
shall be paid by the village. The bond shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Treasurer
shall take and subscribe the oath required by the Illinois Constitution. The
subscribed oath shall be filed in the office of the Village Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation. The Treasurer shall receive compensation in such
amount and manner as the President and Board of Trustees shall fix from time
to time by contract or ordinance.



('81 Code, § 2-6.03) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.063  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   The Treasurer shall perform such duties as may be prescribed for him by
statute or ordinance. He shall receive all money paid into the hands of such
other officer or employee as may receive it, and he shall pay out money only
on vouchers or orders properly signed by the Village President and the
Village Clerk. In addition, the Treasurer shall collect and receive all money
due on special assessments and special taxes, and shall keep such records
pertaining to such collection as may be required by statute or ordinance. All
monies received on any special assessment shall be held by the Treasurer to
be applied only to the payment of the improvement or bonds and vouchers
issued therefor, together with interest thereon, for which the assessment was
made. Payments on bonds or vouchers shall be made in accordance with the
statutes.



('81 Code, § 2-6.04) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.064  DEPOSIT OF FUNDS.



   The Treasurer shall deposit the village funds not less frequently than
once each week in such depositories as may be selected from time to time as
provided by law; and he shall keep the deposits of the village money separate
and distinct from his own money, and shall not make private or personal use
of any village money.



('81 Code, § 2-6.05) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.065  RECORDS AND REPORTS.



   (A)   The Treasurer shall keep records showing all money received
and paid out by him, showing the source from which it is received and the
purpose for which it is paid, and he shall keep records at all times showing
the financial status of the village.



   (B)   The Treasurer shall make such reports regarding delinquent
special assessments as are required by statute, and shall make a monthly
report to the Board of Trustees showing what money has been received and the
sources thereof. The Treasurer shall also make an annual report during the
last month of the fiscal year showing the activities of his office.



('81 Code, § 2-6.06) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.066  ACCOUNTS.



   The Treasurer shall keep such books and accounts, as may be required by
statute or ordinance, and he shall keep them in the manner required by the
Board of Trustees.



('81 Code, § 2-6.07) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.067  WARRANTS, TRANSFER OF FUNDS.



   All warrants drawn on the Treasury must be signed by the Village
President and countersigned by the Village Clerk, stating the particular fund
or appropriation to which the same is chargeable, and the person to whom
payable.



('81 Code, § 2-6.08) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



BUDGET OFFICER



§ 31.080  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Budget Officer.



('81 Code, § 2-7.01) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.081  APPOINTMENT.



   The Budget Officer shall be appointed by the Village President by and
with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, to serve a term of one
year, unless otherwise extended by contract, but in no event longer than the
term of the current Village President. Removal from office shall be in like
manner in accordance with applicable state law and contractual provisions.
The Budget Officer may hold another non-conflicting municipal office, either
elected or appointed.



('81 Code, § 2-7.02) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.082  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Budget
Officer shall furnish a surety bond in the amount to be approved by the
President and Board of Trustees, the bond to be conditioned on the faithful
performance of the Budget Officer's duties. The premium for the bond shall be
paid by the village. The bond shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Budget
Officer shall take and subscribe the oath required by the Illinois
Constitution. The subscribed oath shall be filed in the office of the Village
Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation. The Budget Officer shall receive compensation in
such amount and manner as the President and Board of Trustees shall fix from
time to time by contract or ordinance.



('81 Code, § 2-7.03) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.083  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Budget Officer shall have the following powers and duties:



      (1)   Permit and encourage and establish the use of efficient
planning, budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting and other fiscal
management procedures in all Municipal departments, commissions and boards.



      (2)   Compile an annual budget in accordance with ILCS Ch. 65,
Act 5, § 8-2-9.3.



      (3)   Examine all books and records of all municipal
departments, commissions and boards which relate to monies received and paid
out, debts and accounts receivable, and amounts owed by or to the village.



      (4)   Obtain such additional information from the village,
municipal departments, commissions and boards as may be useful to the Budget
Officer for purposes of compiling a municipal budget, such information to be
furnished by the village, municipal departments, commissions and boards in
the form required by the Budget Officer. Any department, commission or board
which refuses to make such information as is requested of it available to the
Budget Officer shall not be permitted to make expenditures under any
subsequent budget for the village until such municipal department, commission
or board shall comply in full with the request of the Budget Officer.



      (5)   Establish and maintain such procedures as shall insure
that no expenditures are made by the village departments, commissions or
boards except as authorized by the budget.



   (B)   Subject to prior written approval of the Budget Officer, the
heads of municipal departments are hereby authorized to delete, add to,
change or create subclasses within object classes budgeted previously to
their departments.



('81 Code, § 2-7.04) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§§ 31.100  through 31.103  RESERVED.



DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS



§ 31.110  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Director of Public Works.



('81 Code, § 2-9.01) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.111  APPOINTMENT.



   The Director of Public Works shall be appointed by the Village
President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, to
serve a term of one year, unless otherwise extended by contract, but in no
event longer than the term of the current Village President. Removal from
office shall be in like manner in accordance with applicable state law and
contractual provisions. The Director of Public Works may hold another
non-conflicting municipal office, either elected or appointed.



('81 Code, § 2-9.02) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.112  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Director
of Public Works shall furnish a surety bond in the amount to be approved by
the President and Board of Trustees, the bond to be conditioned on the
faithful performance of the Director of Public Works's duties. The premium
for the bond shall be paid by the village. The bond shall be filed with the
Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Director
of Public Works shall take and subscribe the oath required by the Illinois
Constitution. The subscribed oath shall be filed in the office of the Village
Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation. The Director of Public Works shall receive
compensation in such amount and manner as the President and Board of Trustees
shall fix from time to time by contract or ordinance.



('81 Code, § 2-9.03) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.113  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Director of Public Works shall have the following powers
and duties:



      (1)   Village property.  The Director of Public Works shall
keep a current inventory of all real and personal property of the village and
the locations of such property. The Director of Public Works shall be
responsible for the care and custody of all village property which is not
assigned to some other officer or body for care and control;



      (2)   Meetings. The Director of Public Works shall attend all
meetings as prescribed by the Village President, Board of Trustees or village
Administrator. It is understood that attendance at these meetings is a
fundamental component of the Director’s duties, and no additional
compensation will be provided for attending the meetings;



      (3)   Streets. The Director of Public Works shall have charge
of the construction and care of all public streets, alleys and driveways in
the village, and keeping the same clean. The Director shall see to it that
all gutters and drains therein function properly and that the same are kept
free from defects;



      (4)   Street lighting. The Director of Public Works shall
supervise the lighting of the public streets and alleys, and keep the
lighting system in efficient operation and good repair.



      (5)   Waterworks. The Director of Public Works shall have
charge of the operation and maintenance of the municipal water distribution
system.



      (6)   Sewers. In the absence of provisions to the contrary,
the Director shall have charge of the construction and maintenance of all
public sanitary and storm water sewers in the village.



      (7)   Inspections Department. In the absence of provisions to
the contrary, the Director shall supervise all activities of the Inspections
Department.



      (8)   Public Works Department.



         (a)   The Director of Public Works shall be responsible
for technical and administrative work in planning, organizing and directing
the activities of the Public Works Department. Supervision shall be exercised
over subordinate technical and clerical personnel in various departmental
activities.



         (b)   All officers or employees assigned to the
Department of Public Works shall perform their duties subject to the orders
and under the supervision of the Director of Public Works. The Director shall
confer with and advise subordinate personnel on work problems, conduct
meetings with technical staff, explain work techniques and resolve
operational problems when necessary for the efficient operation of the Public
Works Department.



   (B)   Work shall be performed under the general administrative
direction of the Village Administrator and shall be reviewed through
conferences, reports and independent audits. The Director shall supervise and
review general procedures, methods and results of the various functional
units of the Public Works Department.



(‘81 Code, § 2-9.04) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98; Am. Ord. 2001-44,
passed 9-10-01; Am. Ord. 2010-24, passed 5-3-10)



§ 31.114  RESERVED.



§ 31.115  STOP WORK ORDERS.



   The Director shall have the power to order all work stopped on
construction, alteration or repair of buildings in the village when such work
is being done in violation of any provision of any ordinance relating thereto
or in violation of the zoning regulations of the village. Work shall not be
resumed after the issuance of such an order except on the written permission
of the Director; provided, however, that if the stop work order is an oral
one, it shall be followed by a written stop work order within an hour, Such
stop work order may be served by any building official or police officer.



('81 Code, § 2-9.06) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.116  ENTRY POWERS.



   The Director shall have the power to make or cause to be made an entry
into any building or premises where the work of altering, repairing or
constructing of any building or structure is going on, for the purpose of
making inspections at any reasonable hour, upon consent of the owner of the
building or premises, or upon execution of an administrative warrant issued
by a Court of competent jurisdiction.



('81 Code, § 2-9.07) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.117  COPIES OF PERMITS TO ASSESSOR.



   In addition to all other duties, the Director shall forward to the
Township Assessor and County Assessor a copy of each building permit issued
within fifteen (15) days of such issuance. Each such copy shall show the
legal description of the lot or area concerned, and the real estate index
number, if any.



('81 Code, § 2-9.08) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



DIRECTOR OF COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT



§ 31.120  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Director of Community Development.



(Ord. 2001-44, passed 9-10-01)



§ 31.121  APPOINTMENT.



   The Director of Community Development shall be appointed by the Village
President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, to
serve a term of one year, unless otherwise extended by contract, but in no
event longer than the term of the current Village President.  Removal from
office shall be in like manner and in accordance with applicable state law
and contractual provisions.  The Director of Community Development may hold
another non-conflicting municipal office, either elected or appointed.



(Ord. 2001-44, passed 9-10-01)



§ 31.122  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond.  Before entering upon the duties of office, the
Director of Community Development shall furnish a surety bond in the amount
to be approved by the President and Board of Trustees, the bond to be
conditioned on the faithful performance of the Director of Community
Development's duties.  The village shall pay the premium for the bond.  The
bond shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath.  Before entering upon the duties of office, the
Director of Community Development shall take and subscribe the oath required
by the Illinois Constitution.  The subscribed oath shall be filed in the
office of the Village Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation.  The Director of Community Development shall
receive compensation in such amount and manner as the President and Board of
Trustees shall fix from time to time by contract or ordinance.



(Ord. 2001-44, passed 9-10-01)



§ 31.123  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Director of Community Development shall have the following
powers and duties:



      (1)   Planning, zoning, and land use administration. The
Director of Community Development shall be generally responsible for
planning, budgeting, organizing, staffing, and supervising the administration
of the zoning ordinance and the subdivision ordinance.  The Director shall
also coordinate annexation petitions, administer development and subdivision
negotiations and agreements; administer and supervise development planning;
review development ordinances; and assist the Planning and Zoning Commission
in the fulfillment of its duties.



      (2)   Meetings. The Director of Community Development shall
attend all Planning and Zoning Commission and other meetings as prescribed by
the Village President, Board of Trustees or Village Administrator. 
Attendance at these meetings is a fundamental component of the Director's
duties, and no additional compensation will be provided for attending the
meetings.



      (3)   Building Department.  The Director of Community
Development shall also supervise the Building Department. It shall be the
duty of the Director of Community Development to supervise the inspection of
all buildings and structures being constructed, repaired or altered, as
frequently as may be necessary to insure compliance with village ordinances
and to supervise those individuals empowered to act as code enforcement
officers, building inspectors, and plumbing inspectors. The Director of
Community  Development and those individuals empowered to act as code
enforcement officers, building inspectors, and plumbing inspectors, as well
as Police Officers (collectively "Code  Enforcement Officers") are empowered
to issue citations for offenses pertaining to property and health and safety
(e.g., Chapters 50, 91, 93, 94, 95, 131, and 136), as well as violations of
Title XV, including building regulations, flood hazards and other land use
controls and codes, and further including but not limited to the subdivision
and zoning ordinances.  The Director of Community Development and the Code
Enforcement Officers shall prosecute said citations through the Code Hearing
Department in accordance with the procedures set forth in the Village Code of
Ordinances.



   (B)   Work shall be performed under the general administrative
direction of the Village Administrator and shall be reviewed through
conferences, reports and independent audits.  The Director shall supervise
and review general procedures, methods and results of the various functional
units of the Community Development Department.



   (C)   All employees assigned to the Community Development Department
shall perform their duties subject to the orders and under the supervision of
the Director of Community Development.  The Director shall confer with and
advise subordinate personnel on work problems, conduct meetings with
technical staff, explain work techniques and resolve operational problems
when necessary for the efficient operation of the Community Development
Department.  The Director of Community Development shall arrange for each
Code Enforcement Officer issuing a citation to attend the hearing and other
proceedings of the Code Hearing Department, and the Director may call upon
the Village Attorney for assistance in prosecuting said matters as the
Director shall, in his or her discretion, deem appropriate.



(Ord. 2001-44, passed 9-10-01; Am. Ord. 2002-70, passed 8-12-02; Am. Ord.
2007-53, passed 9-4-07)



DIRECTOR OF PARKS AND RECREATION



§ 31.130  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Director of Parks and Recreation.



('81 Code, § 2-11.01) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.131  APPOINTMENT.



   The Director of Parks and Recreation shall be appointed by the Village
President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, to
serve a term of one year, unless otherwise extended by contract, but in no
event longer than the term of the current Village President. Removal from
office shall be in like manner in accordance with applicable state law and
contractual provisions. The Director of Parks and Recreation may hold another
non-conflicting municipal office, either elected or appointed.



('81 Code, § 2-11.02) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.132  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Director
of Parks and Recreation shall furnish a surety bond in the amount to be
approved by the President and Board of Trustees, the bond to be conditioned
on the faithful performance of the Director of Parks and Recreation's duties.
The premium for the bond shall be paid by the village. The bond shall be
filed with the Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Director
of Parks and Recreation shall take and subscribe the oath required by the
Illinois Constitution. The subscribed oath shall be filed in the office of
the Village Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation. The Director of Parks and Recreation shall
receive compensation in such amount and manner as the President and Board of
Trustees shall fix from time to time by contract or ordinance.



('81 Code, § 2-11.03) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98)



§ 31.133  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Director of Parks and Recreation shall be generally
responsible for planning, budgeting, organizing, publicizing, staffing,
scheduling, and supervising all village recreation programs, personnel,
facilities, and services. The Director shall also be responsible for
planning, designing, and development of all park lands and facilities.



   (B)   The Director of Parks and Recreation shall be responsible for
technical and administrative work in planning, organizing and directing the
activities of the Parks and Recreation Department. Supervision shall be
exercised over subordinate technical and clerical personnel in various
departmental activities.



   (C)   Work shall be performed under the general administrative
direction of the Village Administrator and shall be reviewed through
conferences, reports and independent audits. The Director shall supervise and
review general procedures, methods and results of the various functional
units of the Parks and Recreation Department.



   (D)   All officers or employees assigned to the Department of Parks
and Recreation shall perform their duties subject to the orders and under the
supervision of the Director of Parks and Recreation. The Director shall
confer with and advise subordinate personnel on work problems, conduct
meetings with technical staff, explain work techniques and resolve
operational problems when necessary for the efficient operation of the Parks
and Recreation Department.



   (E)   The Director of Parks and Recreation shall have charge of the
operation and maintenance of the municipal cemetery.



(‘81 Code, § 2-11.04) (Ord. 1998-42, passed 9-14-98; Am. Ord. 2010-24,
passed 5-3-10)



DIRECTOR OF ADMINISTRATIVE SERVICES



§ 31.140  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Director of Administrative
Services.



(Ord. 2016-57, passed 11-7-16)



§ 31.141  APPOINTMENT.



   The Director of Administrative Services shall be appointed by the
Village President by and with the advice and consent of the Board of
Trustees, to serve a term of one year, unless otherwise extended by contract,
but in no event longer than the term of the current Village President.
Removal from office shall be in like manner in accordance with applicable
state law and contractual provisions. The Director of Administrative Services
may hold another non-conflicting municipal office, either elected or
appointed.



(Ord. 2016-57, passed 11-7-16)



§ 31.142  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Director
of Administrative Services shall furnish a surety bond in the amount to be
approved by the President and Board of Trustees, the bond to be conditioned
on the faithful performance of the duties of the Director of Administrative
Services. The premium for the bond shall be paid by the village. The bond
shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Director
of Administrative Services shall take and subscribe the oath required by the
Illinois Constitution. The subscribed oath shall be filed in the office of
the Village Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation. The Director of Administrative Services shall
receive compensation in such amount and manner as the President and Board of
Trustees shall fix from time to time by contract or ordinance.



(Ord. 2016-57, passed 11-7-16)



§ 31.143  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Director of Administrative Services shall be responsible
for technical and administrative work in planning, organizing and directing
the activities of the Administrative Services Department. The Director of
Administrative Services shall also have primary responsibility for drafting,
reviewing and revising financial policies, and for presenting such financial
policies and revisions to the Board of Trustees for adoption. All approved
financial policies shall be kept on file with the Village Clerk for
inspection by the public.



   (B)   Work responsibilities shall include overall administration and
direction of the Administrative Services Department, including budgeting,
accounting, purchasing coordination and cash management, debt administration.
Supervision shall be exercised over subordinate technical and clerical
personnel in various departmental activities. Considerable emphasis and
responsibility shall be directed at policy formulation and financial analysis
of village operations as well as the development of effective procedures and
procedural improvements in the fiscal system of the village. Work shall be
performed under the general administrative direction of the Village
Administrator and shall be reviewed through conferences, reports and
independent audits.



   (C)   The Director of Administrative Services shall:



      (1)   Plan, organize, coordinate and direct the financial
operations of the village; supervise and review the general procedures,
methods and results of the various functional units of the Administrative
Services Department including accounting, budgetary data accumulation,
payroll and employee benefit accounting, water billing and payment recording,
receivable and payable accounting, and the coordination of electronic data
processing of the village's financial data.



      (2)   Confer with and advise subordinate personnel on work
problems; conduct meetings with technical staff and explain work techniques
and resolve, operational problems.



      (3)   Direct the maintenance of the central accounting system;
direct the investment of surplus monies as permitted by law; direct the
custody of all monies, funds and securities; meet with representatives of
financial institutions and discuss bond issuance costs and advise the Village
Administrator on the proper administration of bond issues and support
recommendations with necessary information.



      (4)   Develop budget forms and procedures to be used in the
development of the annual village budget; assist department heads in budget
preparation; develop revenue estimates; and, after approval of the budget,
prepare monthly financial statements and assist in solutions to any budgetary
problems.



      (5)   Direct, supervise, and coordinate the administration of
employee benefits, payroll the risk management program, and recruiting
efforts, compensation, performance appraisal process, and legal compliance
matters.



      (6)   Develop cost information and apply cost analysis to
various proposed capital improvements and major village projects.



      (7)   Direct, supervise, and coordinate the administration of
the technology needs of each of the village's departments and facilities; the
village's technology infrastructure including disaster recovery and backups,
voice and data systems, as well as multiple software packages; and PCI
compliance (except as otherwise provided by law).



(Ord. 2016-57, passed 11-7-16)



VILLAGE ENGINEER



§ 31.150  OFFICE CREATED.



   There is hereby created the office of Village Engineer.



(Ord. 2017-09, passed 2-21-17)



§ 31.151  APPOINTMENT AND QUALIFICATIONS.



   (A)   The Village President shall appoint the Village Engineer with
the advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees to serve a term of
one fiscal year (or remainder thereof), but in no event longer than the term
of the current Village President. Removal from office shall be in like manner
and in accordance with applicable state laws and contractual provisions. The
Village Engineer may hold another non-conflicting municipal office, either
elected or appointed.



   (B)   The office of Village Engineer may be filled by a qualified
employee of the village or by contract. The Village Engineer shall be a
registered and licensed design professional or registered and licensed
professional design firm in the State of Illinois. The village may also
contract with other registered and licensed design professionals to
supplement and assist the Village Engineer in fulfilling the duties of the
Office of Village Engineer. The Village Engineer shall perform such duties as
may be assigned by ordinance and by the Village Administrator from time to
time.



(Ord. 2017-09, passed 2-21-17)



§ 31.152  BOND, OATH AND COMPENSATION.



   (A)   Bond. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village
Engineer shall furnish a surety bond in the amount to be approved by the
President and Board of Trustees, the bond to be conditioned on the faithful
performance of the Village Engineer's duties. The premium for the bond shall
be paid by the village. The bond shall be filed with the Village Clerk.



   (B)   Oath. Before entering upon the duties of office, the Village
Engineer shall take and subscribe the oath required by the Illinois
Constitution. The subscribed oath shall be filed in the office of the Village
Clerk.



   (C)   Compensation. The Village Engineer shall receive compensation
in such amount and manner as the President and Board of Trustees shall fix
from time to time by agreement, contract or ordinance.



(Ord. 2017-09, passed 2-21-17)



§ 31.153  POWERS AND DUTIES.



   (A)   The Village Engineer shall be generally responsible for
carrying out the duties required by statute and by ordinance.



   (B)   The Village Engineer shall be responsible for technical and
administrative work in planning, organizing and assisting the Director of
Public Works.



   (C)   Work shall be performed under the general administrative
direction of the Village Administrator and shall be reviewed through
conferences, reports and independent audits.



(Ord. 2017-09, passed 2-21-17)
