COIN-IN-SLOT AMUSEMENT DEVICE



§ 112.01  AUTHORITY TO REGULATE.



   This subchapter is passed pursuant to ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 11-42-2
and 11-55-1, and ILCS Ch. 35, Act 510, §§ 1 et seq., and also pursuant to
the case of Hagen v. the City of Rock Island, in the Illinois Supreme Court,
18 Ill. Sec. 174, 163 NE2d 495.



('81 Code, § 5-3a.02)  (Ord. 1982-5-2, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2010-66, passed 12-20-10)



§ 112.02  FEE.



   There hereby is imposed on the privilege of operating every
coin-in-the-slot amusement device, as defined in § 112.03 of this chapter,
an annual fee of $100 for each such device in excess of two for which the
operator is authorized by the term of his, her, or its license to operate.
This fee does not apply to, and is in addition to any fees applicable to, any
video gaming terminals regulated by the State of Illinois Video Gaming Act
and subject to Chapter 113 of the Village Code of Ordinances. Likewise, video
gaming terminals, as defined by Chapter 113 of the Village Code of
Ordinances, shall not be counted for purposes of determining the applicable
fee due hereunder. Should a licensee hereunder install one or more video
gaming devices on the premises and, in accordance with Chapter 113, §
113.10, remove any coin-in-the-slot amusement devices, then said licensee
shall not be entitled to any refund of any fee paid to the village under this
chapter and section for said coin-in-the-slot amusement devices.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.03)  (Ord. 1982-5-3, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2010-66, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed
11-21-11)



§ 112.03  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   COIN-IN-THE-SLOT AMUSEMENT DEVICE.  Any juke box, pinball machine,
miniature bowling machine, pool table, bumper pool table, or other electronic
game or machine of any kind which upon the insertion of a coin, slug, token,
chip, plate, disc, or similar objects, including but not limited to the swipe
or insertion of an electronic card or key, may be operated by the public
generally for use as a game, entertainment, or amusement, whether or not
registering a score, and said term COIN-IN-THE- SLOT AMUSEMENT DEVICE shall
also include trivia games, video games, marble machines, skill ball,
mechanical grab machines, and all games, operations, or transactions similar
thereto under whatever name they may be known. The term COIN- IN-THE-SLOT
AMUSEMENT DEVICE shall also mean any electronic game machine, device, table,
or implement, whether or not coin operated, but used as a game,
entertainment, or amusement, whether or not registering a score, and whether
or not involving electronic beams or beacons of light. COIN-IN-THE- SLOT
AMUSEMENT DEVICE also includes any electronic video game machine that is
available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including but not
limited to video poker, line up, and blackjack, utilizing a video display and
microprocessors in which the player may receive free games or credits that
cannot be redeemed for cash. In no case does the term COIN-IN-THE-SLOT
AMUSEMENT DEVICE include a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash, or
tokens or that is not exclusively for amusement purposes.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.04)  (Ord. 1982-5-4, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2010-66, passed 12-20-10; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed
11-21-11; Am. Ord. 2012-50, passed 10-1-12)



§ 112.04  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person shall keep or display for operating or patronage by the
public within this village, any said coin-in-the-slot amusement device
without having first obtained a written license therefor from the
Administrator of this village, which license shall be framed and hung in
plain view in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises, and such posted
license may include more than one device on such licensed premises.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.05)  (Ord. 1982-5-5, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-80,
passed 10-17-05; Am. Ord. 2005-88, passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2010-66, passed
12-20-10; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed 11-21-11)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 112.05  NUMBER OF DEVICES ALLOWED.



   The village finds that the operation of an arcade is a nuisance, and
therefore no arcade shall be permitted in this village.  An ARCADE is
defined as an operation in which coin-in-the-slot amusement devices form the
primary enterprise conducted on the premises.  The number of
coin-in-the-slot amusement devices permitted upon a premises at any one time
shall not exceed that number authorized in the license for said premises.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.06)  (Ord. 1982-5-6, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed 11-21-11)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 112.06  APPLICATION FORM REQUIRED.



   An application for an amusement device license shall be made to the
Village Administrator of this village on forms furnished by said Village
Administrator.  The application shall set forth the number of
coin-in-the-slot amusement devices for which permission is sought for a
particular premises, shall describe the number and type of each different
device or machine that the applicant intends to operate, and shall be
accompanied by payment of the appropriate fee. The applicant shall include a
copy of the license from the State of Illinois for each video gaming terminal
at that location.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.07)  (Ord. 1982-5-7, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-80,
passed 10-17-05; Am. Ord. 2005-88, passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2010-66, passed
12-20-10; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed 11-21-11)



§ 112.07  QUALIFICATION OF LICENSEE.



   The term PERSON as used herein shall include any person, firm,
corporation or association, or partnership which owns or possesses or places
for use by the public any such coin-in-the-slot amusement device, and the
term PERSON shall also mean any such person, firm, corporation, partnerships,
or association having control over any such device. Any natural person may be
a licensee only personally and individually, as a member of a partnership, as
an officer, employee, or shareholder of a corporation, or other firm, or as a
member of any association, but not in any combination of same.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.08)  (Ord. 1982-5-8, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed 11-21-11)



§ 112.08  LENGTH OF LICENSE.



   Every license granted hereunder shall expire on December 31 of the year
in which it is granted.  The fee shall not be prorated.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.09)  (Ord. 1982-5-9, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05)



§ 112.09  LICENSE NOT TRANSFERABLE.



   No license issued to any person hereunder shall be transferable to any
other person or for any other premises other than that set forth on the
license. Application must be made annually.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.10)  (Ord. 1982-5-10, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-80,
passed 10-17-05; Am. Ord. 2005-88, passed 11-21-05)



§ 112.10  REGULATION ON DISTURBING THE PEACE.



   No license issued under this subchapter shall permit the operation of
any coin-in-the-slot amusement device at any place or in any manner which
will disturb the peace and quiet of persons outside, or beyond the premises
on which such amusement device is being used.  No immoral or indecent
selection shall be presented in any such amusement device.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.11)  (Ord. 1982-5-11, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed 11-21-11)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 112.11  CONDITIONS GOVERNING LICENSE.



   (A)   In addition to any other condition or regulation contained in
this subchapter or in the statutes of the State of Illinois, the following
conditions and regulations shall be applicable to and shall govern and
control the business of keeping or providing coin-in-the-slot amusement
devices for public use within the village:



      (1)   No coin-in-the-slot amusement device shall be located
within 200 feet of a church, school, or residence in this village; no license
shall be issued for any such device or machine excepting in an area in this
village appropriately zoned for same.



      (2)   The walls, ceiling, or floor, or any combination
thereof, of the building or structure, or portion thereof, containing such
devices shall be insulated or otherwise constructed so that no noise or
vibration that is detectable without the aid of any mechanical device or
instrument will be allowed beyond the outer perimeter of the licensed
premises (compliance with this division shall be verified by appropriate
village inspection before the issuance of any license).



      (3)   No coin-in-the-slot amusement device shall be used for
purposes of or in connection with the wagering of money, goods, or
merchandise upon the outcome of the use or manipulation of such device or
otherwise used for the purpose of gambling as defined in the state statutes.



      (4)   At all times during the hours of operation of the
licensed premises there shall be present a manager or other employee of the
licensee, at least one of whom shall be not less than 18 years of age, to
provide adequate control and supervision of the licensed premises and the use
of the coin-in-the-slot amusement devices present therein.



   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person licensed to engage in the
business of keeping or providing coin-in-the-slot amusement devices for
public use within the village to fail to comply with the conditions and
regulations set forth in division (A) of this section or to suffer or permit
noncompliance with such conditions and regulations on or within the licensed
premises.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.12)  (Ord. 1982-5-12, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed 11-21-11)  Penalty, see § 10.99



§ 112.12  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   Nothing in the provisions of this subchapter shall preclude the right
of the Village President to suspend or revoke the license of the licensee, as
follows:



   (A)   The Village President may temporarily suspend any license
issued under the terms of this subchapter when he or she has reason to
believe that the continued operation of a particular licensed premises will
immediately threaten the welfare of the community or create an imminent
danger of violation of applicable law.  In such case, he or she may, upon
the issuance of a written order stating the reason for such determination and
without notice or hearing, order the licensed premises closed for not more
than seven days, provided that the licensee shall be given an opportunity to
be heard in a public hearing during the seven-day periods and further
provided that if such licensee shall also be engaged in the conduct of other
businesses on the licensed premises, such order shall not be applicable to
such other businesses.



   (B)   The Village President may suspend or revoke any license issued
under the terms of this subchapter upon due notice to the licensee of the
time and place of a public hearing, and a public hearing, if the Village
President determines upon hearing that the licensee has failed or refused to
comply with the terms of this subchapter, has failed or refused to comply
with other law applicable to the business of keeping or providing
coin-in-the-slot amusement devices, or has been convicted by a court of
competent jurisdiction of a violation of any provision of this subchapter.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.13)  (Ord. 1982-5-13, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-80,
passed 10-17-05; Am. Ord. 2005-88, passed 11-21-05; Am. Ord. 2011-56, passed
11-21-11)



§ 112.13  LICENSE RESTRICTIONS.



   No license shall be issued nor shall a licensee be entitled to have a
license continued in effect under any of the following conditions:



   (A)   Any individuals, corporate officer or director, or any
partners as the case may be, has ever been convicted of a felony;



   (B)   Any information on the application is false;



   (C)   The applicant has not reached the age of 18 years;



   (D)   The applicant is not engaged in another business as its
principal business at the same location;



   (E)   The manager or agent has ever been convicted of a felony, or
has not reached the age of 18 years.



('81 Code, § 5-3a.14)  (Ord. 1982-5-14, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-88,
passed 11-21-05)



§ 112.14  INFORMATION REQUIREMENT.



   Applications for the licenses required above shall be filed in
triplicate with said Village Administrator (with one of said copies being
retained, each, by the Village Administrator, by the applicant, and by the
Village Police Chief), and shall contain the following information:



   (A)   If the applicant is a corporation:



      (1)   Corporate name and address.



      (2)   Names, dates of birth, and addresses of corporate
officers and directors.



      (3)   Statement of principal kind of business in which
corporation engages.



      (4)   Statement of whether corporate business will be
conducted by a manager, and the name, address and authority of any such
manager or agent.



      (5)   Names, dates of birth, and addresses of all persons,
firms and organizations owning of record five percent or more of the
corporation's stock.



      (6)   Statement of whether any officer, manager, director, or
shareholder owning five percent or more of the stock of the corporation has
ever been convicted of a felony charge.



      (7)   The location of the place of business where the
coin-operated amusement device is to be kept or displayed.



      (8)   Statement or personal history of the manager or agent
conducting business for the corporation.



      (9)   Any other information which the Village Administrator
shall require.



   (B)   If the applicant is an individual, partnership, or association:



      (1)   Name and address, and date of birth of applicant.



      (2)   Location of place of business.



      (3)   Principal kind of business engaged in.



      (4)   Statement of whether business will be conducted by a
manager or agent, and the name and address and date of birth of any such
manager or agent.



      (5)   The place where the coin-operated amusement devices are
to be displayed and a description of the devices.



      (6)   Statement of personal history of the manager or agent
conducting business for applicant.



      (7)   Any other information which the Village Administrator
shall require.



(‘81 Code, § 5-3a.15)  (Ord. 1982-5-15, passed 2-1-82; Am. Ord. 2005-80,
passed 10-17-05; Am. Ord. 2005-88, passed 11-21-05)



§ 112.15  TIME OF APPLICATION.



   Any such application submitted above shall be submitted at least 30
days prior to the commencement of the period for which the license is sought.



('81 Code, § 5-3a.16)  (Ord. 1982-5-16, passed 2-1-82)



CARNIVALS AND FAIRS



§ 112.45 COMPLIANCE WITH STATE LAW.



   No amusement ride or amusement attraction shall be operated at a
carnival or fair unless the applicant for the special event permit shall
provide the ZoningAdministrator with evidence of compliance with ILCS Ch.
430, Act 85, §§ 2-1 et seq., the Carnival and Amusement Rides Safety Act. 
Such evidence of compliance shall accompany the application for special event
permit (as set forth in § 154.046(G) of the zoning code) and shall
includebut not be limited to the submission of copiesof every permit or
license issued  under the Carnival and Amusement Rides Safety Act.



(Ord. 2005-80, passed 10-17-05)  Penalty see § 10.99



RAFFLES AND POKER RUNS



§ 112.60  DEFINITIONS.



   Unless the context otherwise requires, all words and phrases used
herein shall have the same meaning as the same or similar words or phrases
defined and used in this state law.



   NET PROCEEDS.  The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less
reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees, and other reasonable
operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.



   RAFFLE LICENSING AGENT.  For this village is the Village Clerk.



   STATE LAW.  Whenever reference herein is made to STATE LAW it shall
mean and refer to the Raffles Act, ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, as amended.



('81 Code, § 5-30.01)  (Ord. 1982-13-1, passed 7-6-82)



§ 112.61  QUALIFICATIONS.



   (A)   A license to operate a raffle shall be issued only to bona
fide religious, charitable, labor, business, fraternal, educational, or
veterans organizations that operate without profit to their members and which
have been in existence continuously for a period of five years immediately
before making application for a license and which have had during that entire
five year period a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out their
objects, or to a non-profit fundraising organization that the licensing agent
determines is organized for the sole purpose of providing financial
assistance to an identified individual or group of individuals suffering
extreme financial hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident,
or disaster. A licensing authority may waive the five-year requirement under
this division for a bona fide religious, charitable, labor, business,
fraternal, educational, or veterans’ organization that applies for a
license to conduct a poker run if the organization is a local organization
that is affiliated with and charted by a national or state organization that
meets the five-year requirement.



(ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, § 2(b))



   (B)   No license shall be issued to:



      (1)   Any person whose felony conviction will impair the
person’s ability to engage in the licensed position;



      (2)   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or
gambling promoter;



      (3)   Any person who is not of good moral character;



      (4)   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in
subsections c(1), c(2), or c(3) has a proprietary equitable, or credit
interest, or in which such a person is active or employed;



      (5)   Any organization in which such a person defined in
subsections c(1), c(2), or c(3) is an officer, director or employee, whether
compensated or not;



      (6)   Any organization in which a person defined in
subsections c(1), c(2), or c(3) is to participate in the management or
operation of a raffle as defined by state law.



(ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, § 3) (‘81 Code, § 5-30.02)  (Ord. 1982-13-2,
passed 7-6-82; Am. Ord. 2007-59, passed 10-15-07)



§ 112.62  APPLICATION.



   (A)   Application forms shall be furnished by the Raffle Licensing
Agent and filed with same.  Said applications shall show the following:



      (1)   The name and address of the applicant;



      (2)   The date, time and location at which winning chances
will be determined;



      (3)   Place and date of chartering or incorporation of
applicants if applicable;



      (4)   Name, address, telephone number, social security number,
and date of birth of presiding officer, secretary, and raffle manager or
applicant;



      (5)   The area or areas in which raffle tickets will be sold;



      (6)   A list of prizes and the retail of each prize to be
awarded in a single raffle; and



      (7)   The price to be charged for each ticket sold.



   (B)   The license application shall contain a sworn statement
attesting to the accuracy of the information provided and to the
not-for-profit character of the prospective licensee.  Said statement shall
be signed by the presiding officer, secretary, and raffle manager of that
prospective licensee.



   (C)   An application for a license under this subchapter is valid
for one raffle only.



   (D)   Any raffle in which the aggregate value of the prizes is less
than $500 shall be considered automatically licensed without the necessity of
an application.



('81 Code, § 5-30.03)  (Ord. 1982-13, passed 7-6-82)



§ 112.63  REGULATIONS GOVERNING LICENSES.



   (A)   Conduct of raffles and poker runs.  The conduct of raffles
and poker runs is subject to the following restrictions:



      (1)   The entire net proceeds of any raffle or poker run must
be exclusively devoted to the lawful purposes of the licensee permitted to
conduct that game.



      (2)   No person except a bona fide member of the licensee
organization may participate in the management or operation of the raffle or
poker run.



      (3)   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for
participation in the management or operation of the raffle or poker run.



      (4)   A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the
winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also
licensed under ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15. A premises where a poker run is held is
not required to obtain a license if the name and location of the premises is
listed as a predetermined location on the license issued for the poker run
and the premises does not charge for the use of the premises.



      (5)   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the
area specified on the license, and winning chances may be determined only at
those locations specified in the license for a raffle.



      (6)   A person under the age of 18 years may participate in
the conducting of raffles or chances or poker run only with the permission of
a parent or guardian.  A person under the age of 18 years may be within the
area where winning chances in a raffle or winning hands or scores in a poker
run are being determined only when accompanied by a parent or guardian.



(ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, § 4(a))



   (B)   Raffle limits.



      (1)   The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise
awarded by a licensee in a single raffle, shall not exceed $50,000.



      (2)   The maximum retail value of each prize awarded by a
licensee in a single raffle shall not exceed $50,000.



      (3)   The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle
chance issued or sold, shall not exceed $100.



      (4)   The maximum number of days during which chances may be
issued or sold, shall not exceed 180.



      (5)   The license shall not be valid for more than 210 days.



   (C)   Manager; bond.



      (1)   All operation and conduct of raffles shall be under the
supervision of a single manager as designated on the license application.



      (2)   A manager shall give a fidelity bond in the sum of the
aggregate retail value the prizes as set out on the application.  The bond
shall be in favor of the organization conditioned upon the raffle manager’s
honesty in the performance of his duties.  Said bond shall provide that
notice shall be given in writing to licensing authority not less than 30 days
prior to its cancellation period.  If the retail value of the prizes exceed
$15,000, such bond shall be a corporate surety.



(ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, § 5)



   (D)   Records.



      (1)   Gross receipts from the operation of raffle programs or
poker runs shall be segregated from other revenues of the licensee;
(including bingo gross receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the
same licensee pursuant to license issued by theDepartment of Revenue of the
State of Illinois), and placed in a separate account.  Each organization
shall have separate records of its raffles and poker runs.  The person who
accounts for gross receipts and expenses from the operation of raffles and
poker runs shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of
the organization.



(ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, § 6(b))



      (2)   Each licensee shall keep records of gross receipts,
expenses, and net proceeds for each single raffle at which winning chances in
a raffle or winning hands or scores in a poker run are determined.  All
reasonable operating expenses deducted from gross receipts for each single
raffle shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the
amount, a description of the purchased items or service or other reason for
deduction, and the recipient.  The distribution of net proceeds shall be
itemized as to payee, purpose amount, and date of payment.



(ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, § 6(a))



      (3)   Each licensee, within 30 days of the raffle, shall
report to its membership and to the Raffle Licensing Agent each of the
following:



         (a)   Gross receipts generated by the conducting of the
raffle;



         (b)   An itemized list of all reasonable operating
expenses which have been deducted from the gross receipts;



         (c)   Net proceeds from the conducting of the raffle;



         (d)   An itemized list of the distribution of the new
proceeds; and



         (e)   A list of prize winners.



         (f)   Records required by this section shall be
preserved for three years, and the organization shall make available for
public inspection their records relating to the operation of a raffle at
reasonable times and places.



   (E)   Conducting gambling schemes.  Nothing in this subchapter
shall be construed to authorize the conducting or operating of any gambling
scheme, enterprise, activity, or device other than raffles as provided by
state law.



(‘81 Code, § 5-30.04)  (Ord. 1982-13-4, passed 7-16-82; Am. Ord. 2007-59,
passed 10-15-07)



§ 112.64  FEES.



   There shall be no fee for licenses issued pursuant to this subchapter.



(‘81 Code, § 5-30.05)  (Ord. 1982-13-5, passed 7-6-82; Am. Ord. 2017-63,
passed 10-2-17)



§ 112.65  ADMINISTRATION.



   (A)   The Raffle Licensing Agent shall be charged with the
administration of this subchapter.



   (B)   The authority and jurisdiction of this village to issue a
license to a prospective licensee shall extend only to the limits of this
village, but it is intended by the passage of this subchapter and the
execution of said “Agreement 1, Intergovernmental Cooperation Agreement for
Raffle Licenses,” that the sale of raffle chances outside the borders of
this municipality, for raffles licensed within the limits of this
municipality, is thereby authorized in contiguous unincorporated areas of the
County of Kane, and within the limits of each municipality in the County of
Kane which is a party to said Agreement, being and intended to be, the
“system for the licensing of organizations to operate raffles” referred
to in ILCS Ch. 230, Act 15, § 2.



   (C)   The Raffle Licensing Agent shall act upon a license
application within ten days from the date of the application.



   (D)   The President and Village Clerk and appropriate officers of
this village are hereby authorized and directed to enter into said
Intergovernmental Cooperation Agreement.



('81 Code, § 5-30.06)  (Ord. 1982-13-6, passed 7-6-82)



§ 112.66  VIOLATIONS.



   Failure to comply with any of the requirements of this subchapter shall
constitute a violation. Whoever violates any of the provisions of this
section is subject to class C misdemeanor provisions, which are 30 days’
imprisonment and/or a fine of $500. Each day the violation continues shall be
considered a separate offense.



(‘81 Code, § 5-30.07)  (Ord. 1982-13-7, passed 7-6-82; Am. Ord. 2007-59,
passed 10-15-07)



§ 112.67  ABATEMENT.



   The imposition of the penalties herein prescribed shall not preclude
the State's Attorney from instituting appropriate action to prevent unlawful
raffles or to restrain, correct, or abate a violation of this subchapter or
of the conditions of a raffle license issued pursuant hereto.



('81 Code, § 5-30.07)  (Ord. 1982-13-7, passed 7-6-82)



CHAPTER 113:  VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS



Section



   113.01   Authority to regulate



   113.02   Fee



   113.03   Definition



   113.04   License required



   113.05   Number of devices allowed



   113.06   Application form required



   113.07   Length of license



   113.08   License not transferable



   113.09   Regulation on disturbing the peace



   113.10   Conditions governing license



   113.11   Suspension or revocation of license



   113.12   Information requirement



   113.13   Time of application



§ 113.01  AUTHORITY TO REGULATE.



   This chapter is passed pursuant to ILCS Ch. 230, Act 40, §§ 1 et seq.
(the Illinois Video Gaming Act).



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.02  FEE.



   There is hereby imposed on the privilege of operating every video
gaming terminal in this village, as defined by the Illinois Video Gaming Act,
ILCS Ch. 230, Act 40, §§ 1 et seq., an annual fee of $25 for each such
device.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.03  DEFINITION.



   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.



   PERSON. As used herein shall include any person, firm, corporation or
association, or partnership which, as permitted by state law and regulation,
owns or possesses or places for use by the public any video gaming device,
and shall also mean any such person, firm, corporation, partnerships or
association having control over any such device.



   VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL. The same meaning as set forth in the Illinois
Gaming Act, ILCS Ch. 230, Act 40, § 65.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.04  LICENSE REQUIRED.



   No person shall keep or display for operating or patronage by the
public within this village, any video gaming terminal without having first
obtained a license therefor from the village, through the Chief of Police.
The license from the village for each terminal shall be in the form of a
sticker that shall be affixed to the particular terminal for which it is
issued. It shall be a prerequisite to any license from the village that the
person keeping the video gaming terminal have a valid license from the State
of Illinois for each such video gaming terminal and the loss or suspension of
any such license by the State of Illinois shall automatically result in the
same status for the license issued hereunder, without refund of any license
fee. Pursuant to state regulation, the village, through the Chief of Police,
shall also report to the State of Illinois any discipline or change in status
of any video gaming licenses issued hereunder.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11; Am. Ord. 2013-54, passed 11-18-13)



§ 113.05  NUMBER OF DEVICES ALLOWED.



   The number of video gaming terminal devices permitted upon a licensed
premises at any one time shall not exceed that number authorized in the
license issued for said premises by the State of Illinois.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.06  APPLICATION FORM REQUIRED.



   An application for a video gaming license shall be made to the Chief of
Police on forms furnished by the Chief of Police. The application shall set
forth the number of video gaming terminals for which permission is sought for
a particular premises; shall include a copy of the license from the State of
Illinois for each video gaming terminal for which an application to the
village is being made; and shall be accompanied by payment of the appropriate
fee.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.07  LENGTH OF LICENSE.



   Every license granted hereunder shall expire on December 31 of the year
in which it is granted. The fee shall not be prorated.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.08  LICENSE NOT TRANSFERABLE.



   No license issued to any person hereunder shall be transferable to any
other person or for any other premises other than that set forth on the
license. Application must be made annually.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.09  REGULATION ON DISTURBING THE PEACE.



   No license issued under this subchapter shall permit the operation of
any video gaming terminal at any place or in any manner which will disturb
the peace and quiet of persons outside, or beyond the premises on which such
amusement device is being used. No immoral or indecent selection shall be
presented in any such device.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.10  CONDITIONS GOVERNING LICENSE.



   (A)   In addition to any other condition or regulation contained in
this subchapter or in the statutes of the State of Illinois, no video gaming
terminal shall be located in any establishment that does not have a valid and
current liquor license from the village.



   (B)   No license issued hereunder shall permit the operation on the
same premises of any coin-in-the-slot amusement devices, as defined in
Chapter 112 of the Village Code of Ordinances, that simulate any of the games
found on video gaming terminals. Licensees may remove such coin-in-the-slot
amusement devices from the premises at the time of obtaining their video
gaming license from the village and such removal shall be a precondition to
the operation of any video gaming terminals. No refund of any fees paid or
other credit shall be given for the removal of such coin-in-the-slot
amusement devices.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.11  SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.



   Nothing in the provisions of this chapter shall preclude the right of
the Village President to suspend or revoke the license of the licensee, as
follows:



   (A)   The Village President may temporarily suspend any license
issued under the terms of this chapter when he or she has reason to believe
that the continued operation of a particular licensed premises will
immediately threaten the welfare of the community or create an imminent
danger of violation of applicable law. In such case, he or she may, upon the
issuance of a written order stating the reason for such determination and
without notice or hearing, order the licensed premises closed for not more
than seven days, provided that the licensee shall be given an opportunity to
be heard in a public hearing during the seven-day periods and further
provided that if such licensee shall also be engaged in the conduct of other
businesses on the licensed premises, such order shall not be applicable to
such other businesses.



   (B)   The Village President may suspend or revoke any license issued
under the terms of this chapter upon due notice to the licensee of the time
and place of a public hearing, and a public hearing, if the Village President
determines upon hearing that the licensee has failed or refused to comply
with the terms of this chapter, has failed or refused to comply with other
law applicable to the business of keeping or providing video gaming devices
or has been convicted by a court of competent jurisdiction of a violation of
any provision of this chapter.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.12  INFORMATION REQUIREMENT.



   Applications for the licenses required above shall be filed in
duplicate with the Chief of Police (with one of said copies being retained,
each, by the Chief of Police and by the applicant), and shall contain the
following information:



   (A)   If the applicant is a corporation:



      (1)   Corporate name and address.



      (2)   Names, dates of birth, and addresses of corporate
officers and directors.



      (3)   Statement of principal kind of business in which
corporation engages.



      (4)   Statement of whether corporate business will be
conducted by a manager, and the name, address and authority of any such
manager or agent.



      (5)   Names, dates of birth, and addresses of all persons,
firms and organizations owning of record five percent or more of the
corporation’s stock.



      (6)   Statement of whether any officer, manager, director, or
shareholder owning five percent or more of the stock of the corporation has
ever been convicted of a felony charge.



      (7)   The location of the place of business where the video
gaming device is to be kept or displayed.



      (8)   Statement or personal history of the manager or agent
conducting business for the corporation.



      (9)   Any other information which the Village Administrator
shall require.



   (B)   If the applicant is an individual, partnership, or association:



      (1)   Name and address, and date of birth of applicant.



      (2)   Location of place of business.



      (3)   Principal kind of business engaged in.



      (4)   Statement of whether business will be conducted by a
manager or agent, and the name and address and date of birth of any such
manager or agent.



      (5)   The place where the video gaming devices are to be
displayed and a description of the devices.



      (6)   Statement of personal history of the manager or agent
conducting business for applicant.



      (7)   Any other information which the Village Administrator
shall require.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



§ 113.13  TIME OF APPLICATION.



   Any such application submitted above shall be submitted at least 30
days prior to the commencement of the period for which the license is sought.



(Ord. 2011-55, passed 11-21-11)



CHAPTER 114:  [RESERVED]



CHAPTER 115:  PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND SCAVENGERS



Section

   115.07   Charitable solicitation on the highway

   115.20.02   Findings

   115.24   Revocation or denial
